body:
Looks great!
(1) I like the organization that @elibrumbaugh suggested. Can we name the tab "Relative" vs. Defaults. Custom is good.
(2) Re: the inclusive/exclusive that @michellethomas brought up, I think that belongs in an info hover as opposed to trying to name the fields accordingly
(3) Ok/Cancel are good.  @GabeLoins do you want to adopt this as well for your metric popover (vs. Save/Close)? For consistency, I'd also move your buttons to the lower right since that's more natural than over to the lower left. Cancel (no color) should be to the left of OK (teal superset color)

# [Codecov](https://codecov.io/gh/apache/incubator-superset/pull/5062?src=pr&el=h1) Report
> Merging [#5062](https://codecov.io/gh/apache/incubator-superset/pull/5062?src=pr&el=desc) into [master](https://codecov.io/gh/apache/incubator-superset/commit/4c44223234b1533660e9faa14a3de57e955b89ef?src=pr&el=desc) will **not change** coverage.
> The diff coverage is `n/a`.

[![Impacted file tree graph](https://codecov.io/gh/apache/incubator-superset/pull/5062/graphs/tree.svg?width=650&src=pr&token=KsB0fHcx6l&height=150)](https://codecov.io/gh/apache/incubator-superset/pull/5062?src=pr&el=tree)

```diff
@@           Coverage Diff           @@
##           master    #5062   +/-   ##
=======================================
  Coverage   77.52%   77.52%           
=======================================
  Files          44       44           
  Lines        8707     8707           
=======================================
  Hits         6750     6750           
  Misses       1957     1957
```



------

[Continue to review full report at Codecov](https://codecov.io/gh/apache/incubator-superset/pull/5062?src=pr&el=continue).
> **Legend** - [Click here to learn more](https://docs.codecov.io/docs/codecov-delta)
> `Δ = absolute <relative> (impact)`, `ø = not affected`, `? = missing data`
> Powered by [Codecov](https://codecov.io/gh/apache/incubator-superset/pull/5062?src=pr&el=footer). Last update [4c44223...60c3ccc](https://codecov.io/gh/apache/incubator-superset/pull/5062?src=pr&el=lastupdated). Read the [comment docs](https://docs.codecov.io/docs/pull-request-comments).

> (1) I like the organization that @elibrumbaugh suggested. Can we name the tab "Relative" vs. Defaults. Custom is good.

@vylc, "relative" is not a good name for the first tab because the second one can also be relative, eg, you could have "last Sunday" as the start and "today" as the end time.
I only see filters tests for `componentDidUpdate`. We should also test dashboard's default_filters from metadata are pre-populated.

For now I think you'll have to use a `Table` visualization.

In the future I'd like to have `Markup` visualization support templating so that you could fetch data from within that context.
```
## Days since last refresh
{{ fetch_sql_results("SELECT ...") }}
```

@mistercrunch it looks like this broke the time shift color assignment (that you fixed here https://github.com/apache/incubator-superset/pull/4202), but it seemed like that broke the verbose names in time shift. Any thoughts on how to solve for both cases?
Fixed in pr #5056

> `Δ = absolute <relative> (impact)`, `ø = not affected`, `? = missing data`
> Powered by [Codecov](https://codecov.io/gh/apache/incubator-superset/pull/5065?src=pr&el=footer). Last update [d322e48...32b2c54](https://codecov.io/gh/apache/incubator-superset/pull/5065?src=pr&el=lastupdated). Read the [comment docs](https://docs.codecov.io/docs/pull-request-comments).

Agree this would be killer addition.  Right now, we use a variety of Druid datasources at varying grain.  To integrate would normally require pre-ingest ETL or post ingest conforming.  Annotations that can "layer" on the Superset side would be an awesome way to integrate without ETL or ingestion changes.  I would also ask if Annotations would allow for Line/Bar combination overlays or has to map to the specific NVD3 chart?  In plotly there is the option of adding traces, would Superset allow something like that possibly?
@mistercrunch @graceguo-supercat can one of you merge if `formData[k] && !Array.isArray(formData[k])` looks ok to you?
abandoning because of a weird git state after rebasing `dashboard-builder`. see #5066

@sebastianwindeck @mistercrunch Get it. I forgot to run `superset init` after upgrading. I will try to check it.
Actually after thinking a bit more I'm thinking while this fixes the problem in the explore view, I don't think it fixes the issue in the dashboard view.
Ok Thanks!
@michellethomas maybe we need to refactor some sort of `formDataInterceptor` method that intercepts and modifies formData on the way in and executes for both Explore and Dashboard.
Mind adding incremental values while at it? Maybe `15 minutes`, `30 minutes`, `1 hour`, `6 hours`, ...
It should yes, where does the lack of access show up? In the datasource list? explore view? dashboard view?
https://github.com/apache/incubator-superset/pull/4819 added this functionality (for lines only though)
This is likely an issue with the SQLAlchemy dialect for db2
Not resolved, someone needs to submit a PR with the changes above.
Is this on Postgres? Sometimes there's confusion around namespacing (connection, database, schema, user, ...)
Oh good idea! done
This pr was broken by me and I resubmitted one #5070  :joy: @mistercrunch`

Ok, thank. I have open a new issue in ibm_db group.

Just to make sure...one can now use BigQuery via SQLAlchemy in Superset? 

Not seeing any updates in the documentation: https://github.com/apache/incubator-superset yet

Yes .. it just hasnt made it to the published page yet...

BigQuery pip install pybigquery bigquery://

Great! Thanks for the quick reply :) If I can add my 2 cents. Would be great to see an example of how to do the complete set-up in steps and perhaps an example covering the querying of a public BQ Dataset: https://cloud.google.com/bigquery/public-data/ It would help to explain the difference between running query in Standard SQL vs Legacy SQL.
@graceguo-supercat merging this, unsure why the python3.6 builds are failing
Also getting similar error message ([Errno 13] Permission denied: '/usr/local/lib/python3.5/site-packages/superset/app') despite updating to newest version.

This problem occurs because your python version is 3.x.
The urlparse module is renamed to urllib.parse in Python 3.

 Lower the python version, or replace import urlparse with import urllib.parse.
@TianyangLi I have changed into MySQL for superset metadata.
Same problem happened to me. I will try to `pip install mysqlclient` and use plain `mysql://` for SQLALCHEMY_DATABASE_URI.

Maybe unrelated, but does the query really work in other clients? To me the EventName    column does not look like an aggregation function (dictGetString). I.e., doesn't it need to be in the group by clause?
I'm not experienced with Clickhouse, though...

it was not changed since we upgraded from a 0.23.x version... so yes...
the function is no aggregation function, it's simply a lookup in an inmemory map, translating an id to a name

Was able to resolve the issue after turning the log level of App_builder to debug. Can edit the https://github.com/apache/incubator-superset/blob/master/superset/__init__.py line number 80 to change log level to DEBUG.

@betodealmeida it seems like the Druid SQL spec is constantly evolving and it seems like `TIME_FLOOR` was introduced in [0.11.0](http://druid.io/docs/0.11.0/querying/sql.html) (it's absent in [0.10.1](http://druid.io/docs/0.10.1/querying/sql.html) where these use `FLOOR(__time TO <granularity>)`). Is there a way to make time grains work for the various versions? Note I'm not sure what Druid versions Superset supports.
Great, thanks guys for the reply and the docs update 👍
update: this is what explore logging looks like now

The solution should be looked in the browser that you are using (that is the answer on the same question I got). I am having the same issue with Superset==0.25, but with previous ==0.24, everything was fine. Taking this into account, I am not sure that the problem is in the browser, but in the new version of Superset (possibly some restrictions).
okay i tried a couple of things , it worked for me when i selected the VIEW from SQL LAB tab and then SQL EDITOR   and selected the view from there
It worked for me when i clicked  the  SQL LAB tab and then SQL EDITOR and selected the view from there, Hope this helps

same here
@graceguo-supercat can you explain it？
One nice way to fix these is by importing `from builtins import str` so that python2.7 will use str as unicode string instead of byte string.

The datetime issue was already mentioned in https://github.com/apache/incubator-superset/issues/786 and the commit https://github.com/apache/incubator-superset/commit/9cdd289081b9e5faf9f8136151502398f6c01369 fixed it but the is_timeseries boolean is again at True.

I found this issue while using python2.7, don't use str here. actually, I think it's not right to use str() here even with python2.7, eg, utf8 bytes, chinese characters will raise exception. @xrmx the origin patch was 
-                series_title = [str(title) for title in name]
+                series_title = [title for title in name]
             elif isinstance(name, tuple):
-                series_title = tuple(str(title) for title in name)
+                series_title = tuple(title for title in name)
             else:
-                series_title = str(name)
+                series_title = name
and run gunicore with PYTHONIOENCODING="utf8" to fix that. and I git log the history, found the refered commit. and that way seems easy for guys to handle.
@zjj http://python-future.org/str_object.html

@xrmx  
ah, I misunderstand your reply, I am not familiar with python3 and I doubt the origin patch that removed 'str()' would do something stupid with python3, so there comes the six.text_type for both python3 and python2.

> Powered by [Codecov](https://codecov.io/gh/apache/incubator-superset/pull/5100?src=pr&el=footer). Last update [4e3b2e7...f7c48da](https://codecov.io/gh/apache/incubator-superset/pull/5100?src=pr&el=lastupdated). Read the [comment docs](https://docs.codecov.io/docs/pull-request-comments).
Actually this seems to solve part of the problem but not all of it. This is still a WIP.

I think we agree that we need a way to prevent users from running infinite billion rows query that will hurt the db server, network, web server and ultimately crash their browser. 

Now we've been doing this two ways depending on the DB engine, `fetchmany`, which I think puts too much strain on the database server. It's rough on Presto/Hive for instance and in many cases is a similar internal cost as running the whole thing from the db's perspective. Then there's the wrap-in-a-subquery approach, that's better and prefer that to `fetchmany`, though I think many db optimizer won't do as good with that as with the `LIMIT` in the main core query. It requires more complex query editing but is preferable to the subquery approach as it may result in a simpler query plan.

I also looked at how other tools seem to be doing this, and they edit the user query much like we do here, likely for the reasons listed above.

The link should only show for SQLAlchemy datasources. I've been meaning to do something similar from the "View query" modal as well.

Given the current approach,  I think we should `>=1.10.0` and pin in `requirements.txt`, though I'm not very big on this new approach as it's brittle. Any backward compatible change to a lib is pretty much guaranteed to break our vanilla `pip install superset` .

The downside of pinning is potentially missing out on bug fixes and security updates.
